I have often dealt with cysts and lumps over the years, but my breasts starting getting increasingly painful about 5 years ago, and yes, definitely one more than the other. I need to wear a bra 24/7 to relieve the discomfort (the only time I don't have one on is in the shower!). I have had a few breast specialists over the years, and all like to leave benign cysts and other lumps alone unless they are causing significant issue. Basically any surgery causes scar tissue, which complicates later imaging, which can lead to further biopsies and so on. So, if it is benign they like to leave it. As you are aware, it is very common to have these benign lumps and bumps, especially in your 30s and 40s. I know you had a hysterectomy, but are you on hormone replacement therapy or anything of that sort? As some have pointed out, reducing caffeine can help. Some have also found benefits from Evening Primrose, but be cautious of the contradictions and discuss with your doctor.  My own breast specialists hand out pamphlets on Evening Primrose as they have found their patients to get relief from use.  However, if you are on hormone replacement therapy I am not sure how that may play into it for you. I still think of course it is VERY good to be proactive and to get checked out when there are new changes. I hope everything turns out benign for you!
Posts.Title: Fibercystic Breast tissue-Left breast always causing me trouble. CCrill CCrill

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2013 01:31AM - edited Dec 27, 2013 01:35AM by DiveCat marie is right. I have had asymmetry from my very first mammogram at 27 but it is just benign fibrocystic changes which are very, very common in pre-menopausal women. Chances are very high your asymmetry is benign too but they need to be sure and to have it recorded for future imaging. 3% of asymmetry means only that....it does not mean they are all malignant findings! It IS vague and not a "negative" finding on its own. I understand the concern...I cone from a high risk family so I'd rather not have anything but a boring clean image, but as I said for me it has always been just (very common) fibrocystic changes. You said your mother, step-mother, and great-aunt had lung cancer & cancer in brain too...was this breast cancer mets (which is not same as lung or brain cancer)? If you are concerned about your risk due to your family history, you may want to consider talking to a genetic counselor to get a true understanding of your risk and look further at your family pattern to see if testing is a possible option. Remember that 75-85% of breast cancer is sporadic (not hereditary) so even though your mother & great-aunt (who is a third-degree relative) both had bc you may not be high risk yourself. Best to talk to a genetics expert though!

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2014 11:18AM DiveCat wrote: In my case I was "high risk" due to family history, so my experience may differ from someone who is told they are "high risk" due to other factors, such as having LCIS or other atypical conditions, whose risk comes from mantle radiation, and so on.  My assessment came from a couple different genetic counselors, after genetic testing and based on my family history. My risk was estimated at a 40% lifetime risk. I had a prophylactic mastectomy and pathology came back clean (no cancer, only other hormonal changes). But, I am 34 and a lifetime risk is exactly that, a lifetime risk and it is not 100%. I may have never got breast cancer, I may have got it at 70, or in my 40s like my relatives, or in 2 years. And, quite frankly, as a mastectomy does not remove all risk, I still may get breast cancer (however, my risk has now been reduced significantly and my risk is now estimated to be below average). Being high risk is not a guarantee you will get cancer, and if you do get cancer there is no real way to determine "when" it would happen. It's a guesstimate at best (say for example you have a family history of early onset breast cancer, in one's 30's and 40's, you may be able to guesstimate that IF you did get cancer, you have a higher chance of also having early onset breast cancer, but again this is STILL not a guarantee you will get cancer, or that if you do you would get it at the same age as your relatives).

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2014 02:17PM - edited Jun 13, 2014 02:26PM by DiveCat leaf,  Where I am, 15-20% is more of a "above average/moderate" risk and they aren't recommended to get high risk screenings, preventative surgeries, and so on. High risk recommendations here start at 20-25%, but even then things like preventative surgeries at that 25% are more on a "case by case basis" rather than "recommended" as they might be for someone with an 80% lifetime risk. The higher risk of "87%" for breast cancer in BRCA+ women is actually based on the original studies which involved certain mutations, and certain families. Now they know that is not the case for all families/carriers (http://www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/factsheet/Risk/BRCA): Breast cancer: About 12 percent of women in the general population will develop breast cancer sometime during their lives (4). By contrast, according to the most recent estimates, 55 to 65 percent of women who inherit a harmful BRCA1 mutation and around 45 percent of women who inherit a harmful BRCA2 mutation will develop breast cancer by age 70 years (5, 6). Ovarian cancer: About 1.4 percent of women in the general population will develop ovarian cancer sometime during their lives (4). By contrast, according to the most recent estimates, 39 percent of women who inherit a harmful BRCA1 mutation (5, 6) and 11 to 17 percent of women who inherit a harmful BRCA2 mutation will develop ovarian cancer by age 70 years (5, 6). It is important to note that these estimated percentages of lifetime risk are different from those available previously; the estimates have changed as more information has become available, and they may change again with additional research. No long-term general population studies have directly compared cancer risk in women who have and do not have a harmful BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation. It is also important to note that other characteristics of a particular woman can make her risk higher or lower than the average risks. These characteristics include her family history of breast, ovarian, and, possibly, other cancers; the specific mutation(s) she has inherited; and other risk factors, such as her reproductive history. However, none of these other factors is as strong as the effect of carrying a harmful BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation. The "average risk" covers the risk for ALL women in the population, so it is skewed by those who are high risk, and those who are very low risk. The individual "base risk" for most women is actually a lot lower than the average, like 3-4%. I think a lot of the differences between the three models in assessments is also greatly explained by the factors they consider. Using the Claus model for example, many women who come from families with male breast cancer, or ovarian cancer, or more than 2 relatives, would potentially be assessed as lower risk they they might really be (from the study you linked): The BRCAPRO model requires a family pedigree as the only input, including age of the individual, ages of relatives, age of onset for particular cancers, and ethnic heritage. This model is designed to predict who is a BRCA-1 or BRCA-2 gene mutation carrier and who is at the risk of developing breast and ovarian cancer. The BRCAPRO model is based on a Mendelian approach that assumes an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. In contrast, the Tyrer-Cuzick model includes family history and a number of other inputs: the individual's age, family history of breast and ovarian cancer, age at menarche, parity, age at first childbirth, age at menopause, use of hormone replacement therapy (HRT), Ashkenazi Jewish heritage, history of breast biopsy and atypical hyperplasia, lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS), height, and body mass index. The model is a statistical model based on the Mayo Clinic Benign Breast Disease cohort, which is made up of 9,376 women, age 18 to 85 years, who had an open breast biopsy between 1967 and 1991. Finally, the Claus model includes the number of first- and second-degree relatives with breast cancer and the age of cancer onset. The Claus model was developed from the cancer and steroid hormone (CASH) population-based, case–control study involving 4,730 patients with histologically documented breast cancer and 4,688 matched controls. This model is based on the premise that breast cancer risk is transmitted as an autosomal-dominant trait and bases the statistical calculation on the genetic relationships between the affected relatives and the woman in question. In terms of outcomes, the lifetime risk of breast cancer estimated by the Tyrer-Cuzick and Claus models includes the risk of both invasive breast cancer and ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), where BRCAPRO predicts only the risk of invasive breast cancer. ..... The widely used version of the Claus model uses family history of only female breast cancer in up to 2 relatives. While a modification of the Claus model includes ovarian cancer, we did not use that model and instead used the model put forth in the ACS guidelines and used by the ACRIN 6666 clinical trial  I was assessed with both BRCAPRO and Tyrer-Cuzick and my results were quite comparable between them with the Tyrer-Cuzick being a bit higher. The Tyrer-Cuzick allows a lot more detailed input and I saw how those factors like parity affected the results and of course if it considers risk of non-invasive cancer that may also explain the higher result. My counselors also referred to Dr. Narod's studies of BRCA-negative families with multiple cases of breast cancer, which found around 40% risk for non-affected relatives. In my own family it is likely there are polygenic factors at play (and I have had other testing for research purposes which supports this likelihood...but there are no clinical guidelines in that case at this point and they just refer to family history). All that being said, I agree prediction is in its infancy. I just did not feel comfortable waiting for it to grow up!

Posts.Content: May 24, 2014 12:16PM - edited May 24, 2014 12:17PM by DiveCat You can definitely request your pathology report, it is your medical information! I ask for copies of all scans, pathologies, etc. If there was anything abnormal he should have disclosed as theses increase personal risk, but there may be many benign changes that he would not necessarily as these are very normal. My pathology showed lots of benign hormonal changes. He may have referred you due to family history alone. Tamoxifen is an accepted preventative option for high risk women. My BRCA test took 3 weeks, through Ambry. My test also tested for some other mutations. I recommend that whatever your results, you see a genetics expert/counselor. I really don't like when doctors skip that step....it is a very important part of the process as a negative result when there is no identified mutation in the family does not mean you are necessarily low risk, and there are other potential hereditary mutations aside from BRCA.

Posts.Content: May 26, 2014 01:29PM DiveCat wrote: Yes, you should have a breast surgeon (a surgeon who has a lot of experience in breast surgery) do the mastectomy, and the plastic surgeon the reconstruction. You want a surgeon who is experienced in high risk patients and protocols to remove the tissue, send for appropriate pathology, etc. For immediate reconstruction, the surgeons will coordinate to find a date that works for them both. For certain reconstructions, like some tissue flap surgeries, there may be even more surgeons in the room at the same time. It seems to be a bit different everywhere, but here I found breast surgeon I liked, consulted with him, and found out who he preferred to work with for PSs, and from those chose what PS I preferred and was referred. After my consult with PS the PS and BS talked more about my surgery and sorted out a date. Both went into OR with me. I also consulted with another breast surgeon and PS at one point, but just felt best about the team I ultimately chose. I also have known women who picked the PS first and worked back from there. Where I live you need a referral to a PS though, so I worked the other way around :) I recommend you pick up a copy of Kathy Steligo's Breast Reconstruction Guidebook, it is very informative about your options, the procedures, and what you can expect.

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2014 03:01PM - edited Apr 27, 2014 03:14PM by DiveCat Pardon me, please, for posting in the Stage IV forum but it seeks this topic has brought people in from all over the boards. All Along88, I am sorry you feel that Jolie's choice was about financial resources. Truth is, she had a very strong family history of BC and OC, and an Ashkenazi Jewish background, her relatives BRCA status was known to be positive, and so she was a candidate for testing in the US, as others would in that situation according to guidelines through their own insurance, etc. Not everyone qualifies for testing, because most cancer IS sporadic (90%) and even BRCA mutations are only responsible about 25% of hereditary cancers. Genetic testing would have been of little benefit for the majority of people who do get cancer. That is not a financial resource thing, but a practical criteria thing. She is BRCA1+ and therefore under guidelines also had access to preventative surgeries, high risk screening, and so on, as do other women....not just famous ones like AJ....do. I am in Canada, with universal healthcare, and she would have been a candidate for free testing here too just based on her family history and ancestry, even if it might have taken a while longer. I had genetic testing, though an am uninformed negative, due to my own family history.  I just had a PBMX last week due to my family history and risk assessment. I do not consider myself "brave", but I do recognize there is difficulty in making a decision to remove healthy breasts, and go through the risks, troubles and pain of mastectomy/reconstruction (and side effects) when the chance is there I also may never have got cancer. Most people in my life seem to realize that as well. I do not like being called brave, but I also do not appreciate my choice being ticked off as "meh! who wouldn't do that..." because really, many would not. And that is a very personal choice that they have the ight to. Even amongst BRCA+ women in the US, uptake for a PBMX is only about 30%. In Canada it is less than 25%. In other parts of the world it is more like 5%. I respect greatly that AJ went public about her choice, despite a LOT of backlash about it (comments about her just wanting a boob job, for example...HA! She is AJ, if she wanted a boob job, she would have had one! Like she did before! It is asinine to think a MX is anything like a boob job!). But, I also know others do not support it. And as I indicated, not everyone would do it even if they had foresight. My own mother who had a Stage III dx, a double MX, 8 rounds of chemo, 6 weeks of rads, now 8 years of anti-hormonals....would not go back in time and do a preventative MX. She still does not understand why I did it in many ways.  So yeah, making that decision knowing that there will be that kind of response is not an easy one. Never mind being so public about it.  I can absolutely understand why people are upset about Amy Robach's comments. On Stage IV forums, and elsewhere. I do not have cancer at all that I know of, and I find her comments rather frustrating and just more pink propaganda. She is a public figure, and there is a responsibility there to communicate accurate information, if you are choosing to communicate about a personal issue. She did not have to be public about her personal battle, but once she chose to be, I do think there is a responsibility there and she failed to meet it. The idea that it is "toughness" that beats cancer may be what she needs to personally cling to deal with her own diagnosis, but it is irresponsible to spread that message as a universal truth. Many, many tough men and women die of cancer every minute.

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2013 05:09PM - edited Nov 18, 2013 05:14PM by DiveCat Yes, do go for a screening mammogram as you are due and point out your concerns to the radiologist/technician, but as was pointed out dense breasts are very common in premenopausal woman so you cannot read anything from that alone. My mammograms read as having asymmetrical heterogeneous density, particularly focused in outer upper quadrant and behind nipple-areola and have the same "disclaimer" that lesions can be obscured in dense tissue (this is because dense tissue shows as white, as do lesions/cancers). I don't trust mammograms alone for me, but that is due to my own high risk/family history, but the density alone is not something I consider suspicious.That disclaimer can be a little unnerving, so I understand your reaction though! Your radiologist will use your past mammograms to compare with your new mammogram. If you do notice any lumps or something that do not show up on a mammogram, you may want to discuss possibility of a follow-up ultrasound or MRI with your radiologist. By the way, I always follow up and ask for a copy of the actual radiologists reporting letter to my primary care doctor, rather than just rely on the "all clear" notice. I keep these in my own personal files so I can see myself what they are reporting on and observing. I have seen a handful of times times where women saw their past reports later only to find out that a radiologist (or radiologists) had been watching a certain area for several mammograms, deeming it not needing immediate follow up/biopsy, before it was raised as an issue. This way if I do have concerns, I can go for a second opinion with my breast surgeon or whatever to discuss it further.
